organization.title: US Fish and Wildlife Service, Department of the Interior

name: evaluation-of-the-source-and-extent-of-lead-poisoning-at-lacreek-national-wildlife-refuge-
notes: The presence of lead shot at levels which would warrant remediation were not identified on any of the study plots. However, trumpeter swans and at least in prior years, Canada geese both have been documented to be affected with lead poisoning. There may be several explanations why densities of lead shot were not found during the study. The methodology described by Anderson (1986) in collecting soil samples is most likely adequate to have identified spent lead shot if it was present on the sites that were surveyed. Thus, the shot may simply not have been there; it may have been buried deeply by past agricultural or water management practices; or the lead shot that geese and swans do ingest were found in areas that were not sampled. Given the distances that geese and swans fly to forage or roost, it is not practical or realistic to develop a sampling protocol that could account for all possible sites where they could encounter spent lead shot. This study attempted to narrow the potential sites by identifying areas where birds were foraging and loafing, or areas that were historically known to have had extensive hunting activity. Both these efforts proved to be unproductive in identifying potential sites for ingestion. Fields for survey were selected based on goose use, and/or hunting pressure. The majority of these were inactive agricultural practice, which includes the tillage of the soil surface. It may be that any shot present on the surface had already been incorporated into the soil profile and is currently not available to foraging geese. Even though lead shot was not found to be a problem in agricultural fields on the refuge, many refuge fields are currently being converted to native grasslands, further eliminating the potential risk of lead shot ingestion. The wetlands that were surveyed were selected based on their past history as duck hunting clubs. Thus, if there were to be any concentrations of lead in refuge wetlands, it would have been on these sites. It is quite possible that during the 65 years of refuge ownership management, the habitat has changed such that past hunting areas are no longer open areas where surveys could take place (e.g., dense stands of cattail were not surveyed due to the inaccessibility of the area to waterfowl and technicians), or the spent lead shot has been buried in sediments past the depth that was surveyed and hopefully past the depth at which swans and geese can access. While the results of this study did not identify sites where geese and swans could potentially access and ingest lead pellets, there are potentially many other sites which could provide access but were simply not surveyed.
title: Evaluation of the source and extent of lead poisoning at Lacreek National Wildlife Refuge, Bennett County, South Dakota
